Posts.Content: soccermom wrote: I met a lady today through my work who apparently received SSI income and had a service dog due to her lymphadema. Has anyone else heard of this? I am a recovered lymphadema patient, now almost 5 years post DX. Mine was very much stress related and once I got through my divorce and all my treatment ( which included a year of herceptin post-surgery and chemo) mine gradually improved. I think it also helped that I educated myself about what to avoid and self-massage. I did not have ssevere swelling but I did have severe discomfort and throbbing when the stress level rose. At times I wondered if life would ever return to "normal". I thought it was encouraging to meet someone who had adapted her lifestyle to cope with lymphadema by receiving SSI and having a service dog to help keep her calm. to dance beneath the diamond sky with one hand waving free Dx 10/20/2003, IDC, <1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 2/12 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: lymphadema as disability soccermom kira

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2008 01:28PM soccermom wrote: I believe the term companion dog is also used interchangeably w/ service dog. I remember how debilitatingÂ lymphadema was and feel very blessed that mine gradually abated. Thank you everyone who shared their experiences and links. bygrace1- how long have you been retired on disability? maybe eventually things will lessen now that you are able to take care of yourself better??

Posts.Content: May 22, 2011 12:54AM soccermom wrote: I have the VUS also, have to look up whether it was on BRCA 1 or 2. Onc recommended other family members be tested, so my dad was tested and HE HAD THE EXACT SAME mutation- my cousin also had BC and should get tested but I feel like she would freak out if I brought it up- it would be of benefit for her two sisters to know I believe- also my brother should be tested but the same thing there- I think it would be upsetting to him for me to bring it up- this really bothers me because my brother's wife's mother died of BC- and his daughter, my niece, could be at higher risk due to that family history ... my sister-in-law did ask about it but never followed up-- it also would help me to know regarding my remaining "good" breast ...
